title: How to Make a Peanut Butter and Banana Sandwich

steps.headline: Spread 1 tablespoon of peanut butter onto each slice of bread.
steps.description: You can use any type of bread you like, but whole wheat bread goes well with bananas and peanut butter. If you'd like, you can also lightly toast the bread first.

steps.headline: Peel and slice a banana.
steps.description: Try to cut the banana as thinly as you can; this will help reduce bulk. About ½-inch (1.27 centimeters) thick slices will be enough.

steps.headline: Place the banana slices onto one of the bread slices.
steps.description: If you wish to make an open-faced sandwich, then place the banana slices onto both pieces of bread. Spread the banana slices across evenly; they should be touching but not overlapping.

steps.headline: Drizzle some honey on top of the bananas.
steps.description: If you'd like, you can also add a sprinkle of cinnamon as well.

steps.headline: Press the two slices of bread together.
steps.description: You can also skip this step, and enjoy the sandwich as an open-faced sandwich instead.

steps.headline: Cut the sandwich in half.
steps.description: You can cut the sandwich vertically or diagonally. This will make it easier to eat and less-likely to fall apart.

steps.headline: Finished.
Pre-heat a skillet or griddle over medium heat.
steps.description: Lightly coat it with cooking spray. For a richer option, you can use 2 tablespoons of butter or other oil instead.

steps.headline: Spread 1 tablespoon of peanut butter onto each slice of bread.
steps.description: You can use any type of bread you like, but whole wheat works best. You can also speed up the grilling time by lightly toasting the bread first. If you like honey, drizzle some honey over the peanut butter. Sprinkle it with cinnamon for an added touch. If you like chocolate, spread 1 tablespoon of Nutella (or other chocolate-hazelnut spread) onto one of the bread slices instead of peanut butter.

steps.headline: Peel and slice a banana.
steps.description: The thinner you slice your banana, the better. It will be less bulky and less likely to fall apart. It will also cook faster.

steps.headline: Place the banana slices onto one of the peanut buttered bread slices.
steps.description: The banana slices should be touching but not overlapping.

steps.headline: Place the other piece of bread, peanut buttered side down, on top.
steps.description: Gently press down on the sandwich. This will seal the sandwich and help it hold together better.

steps.headline: Fry the sandwich, turning once, until it is golden brown on both sides.
steps.description: It will take about 2 minutes per side. Use a spatula to turn the sandwich quickly so that it does not fall apart.

steps.headline: Cut the sandwich in half and serve.
steps.description: Once the sandwich is ready, take it off the skillet or griddle and transfer it to a plate. Cut it in half vertically or diagonally, and serve it while it is still hot.

steps.headline: Spread some peanut butter over one side of the tortilla.
steps.description: Make sure that you cover the entire surface.

steps.headline: Peel and slice a banana.
steps.description: Try to slice it as thinly as possible, about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). If you slice it too thick, your quesadilla will be too bulky and fall apart.

steps.headline: Spread the banana slices over one half of the tortilla.
steps.description: The banana slices should be touching but not overlapping. Leave the other half of the tortilla empty; you will be folding it in half.

steps.headline: Scatter the chocolate chips over the banana slices.
steps.description: You can also use chocolate sauce instead, and drizzle it across the banana slices.

steps.headline: Fold the tortilla in half.
steps.description: Press the peanut buttered side of the tortilla onto the chocolate and banana side. Gently press down on it with a spatula to seal it.

steps.headline: Cook the quesadilla in a skillet over medium-low heat, turning once.
steps.description: Use a spatula to flip the quesadilla over and gently pat it down. It is done when it turns golden brown and crispy on both sides.

steps.headline: Cut the quesadilla into fourths and serve it while it is still hot.
steps.description: Use a spatula to slip the quesadilla onto a large plate. Cut it in half first, then cut each smaller segment in half again.

text: Making a Basic Sandwich Spread 1 tablespoon of peanut butter onto each slice of bread. You can use any type of bread you like, but whole wheat bread goes well with bananas and peanut butter. If you'd like, you can also lightly toast the bread first. Peel and slice a banana. Try to cut the banana as thinly as you can; this will help reduce bulk. About ½-inch (1.27 centimeters) thick slices will be enough. Place the banana slices onto one of the bread slices. If you wish to make an open-faced sandwich, then place the banana slices onto both pieces of bread. Spread the banana slices across evenly; they should be touching but not overlapping. Drizzle some honey on top of the bananas. If you'd like, you can also add a sprinkle of cinnamon as well. Press the two slices of bread together. You can also skip this step, and enjoy the sandwich as an open-faced sandwich instead. Cut the sandwich in half. You can cut the sandwich vertically or diagonally. This will make it easier to eat and less-likely to fall apart. Finished.  Making a Grilled Sandwich Pre-heat a skillet or griddle over medium heat. Lightly coat it with cooking spray. For a richer option, you can use 2 tablespoons of butter or other oil instead. Spread 1 tablespoon of peanut butter onto each slice of bread. You can use any type of bread you like, but whole wheat works best. You can also speed up the grilling time by lightly toasting the bread first. If you like honey, drizzle some honey over the peanut butter. Sprinkle it with cinnamon for an added touch. If you like chocolate, spread 1 tablespoon of Nutella (or other chocolate-hazelnut spread) onto one of the bread slices instead of peanut butter. Peel and slice a banana. The thinner you slice your banana, the better. It will be less bulky and less likely to fall apart. It will also cook faster. Place the banana slices onto one of the peanut buttered bread slices. The banana slices should be touching but not overlapping. Place the other piece of bread, peanut buttered side down, on top. Gently press down on the sandwich. This will seal the sandwich and help it hold together better. Fry the sandwich, turning once, until it is golden brown on both sides. It will take about 2 minutes per side. Use a spatula to turn the sandwich quickly so that it does not fall apart. Cut the sandwich in half and serve. Once the sandwich is ready, take it off the skillet or griddle and transfer it to a plate. Cut it in half vertically or diagonally, and serve it while it is still hot. Making Quesadillas Spread some peanut butter over one side of the tortilla. Make sure that you cover the entire surface. Peel and slice a banana. Try to slice it as thinly as possible, about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). If you slice it too thick, your quesadilla will be too bulky and fall apart. Spread the banana slices over one half of the tortilla. The banana slices should be touching but not overlapping. Leave the other half of the tortilla empty; you will be folding it in half. Scatter the chocolate chips over the banana slices. You can also use chocolate sauce instead, and drizzle it across the banana slices. Fold the tortilla in half. Press the peanut buttered side of the tortilla onto the chocolate and banana side. Gently press down on it with a spatula to seal it. Cook the quesadilla in a skillet over medium-low heat, turning once. Use a spatula to flip the quesadilla over and gently pat it down. It is done when it turns golden brown and crispy on both sides. Cut the quesadilla into fourths and serve it while it is still hot. Use a spatula to slip the quesadilla onto a large plate. Cut it in half first, then cut each smaller segment in half again.
